gesel 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Gene set searches with the Gesel database

    Fetch genes for some sets

    fetchGenesForSomeSets.Rd

    Fetch genes for some sets in the Gesel database. This can be more efficient than fetchGenesForAllSets if only a few sets are of interest.

    fetchGenesForSomeSets(
  species,
  sets,
  fetch.file = downloadDatabaseFile,
  fetch.file.args = list(),
  fetch.range = downloadDatabaseRanges,
  fetch.range.args = list()
)

    Arguments

    species

    String containing the NCBI taxonomy ID of the species of interest.

    sets

    Integer vector containing set indices. Each set index refers to a row in the data frame returned by fetchAllSets.

    fetch.file

    Function that accepts the name of the file in the Gesel database and returns an absolute path to the file.

    fetch.file.args

    Named list of arguments to pass to fetch.file.

    fetch.range

    Function that accepts at least two arguments - the name of the file in the Gesel database, and an integer vector of length 2 containing the zero-indexed half-open byte range to extract from the file (see downloadDatabaseRanges for details). It should return a string containing the contents of the specified byte range.

    fetch.range.args

    Named list of arguments to pass to fetch.file.

    Value

    List of integer vectors. Each vector corresponds to a set in sets and contains the identities of its member genes. Each gene is defined by its gene index, which refers to a row of the data frame returned by fetchAllGenes.

    Author

    Aaron Lun

    Examples

    first.set <- fetchGenesForSomeSets("9606", 1)
str(first.set)
#> List of 1
#>  $ : int [1:11] 205 1357 2947 3050 3397 6394 6929 11392 13719 14489 ...

# Genes in the first set:
gene.symbols <- fetchAllGenes("9606")$symbol
head(gene.symbols[first.set[[1]]])
#> [[1]]
#> [1] "SLC25A4"
#> 
#> [[2]]
#> [1] "TYMP"
#> 
#> [[3]]
#> [1] "MEF2A"
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [1] "MPV17"
#> 
#> [[5]]
#> [1] "OPA1"
#> 
#> [[6]]
#> [1] "LONP1"
#>
